title: LIFT: Improving Long Context Understanding of Large Language Models through Long Input Fine-Tuning
author: Yansheng Mao (Peking University), Yufei Xu (Peking University), Jiaqi Li (BIGAI), Fanxu Meng (Peking University), Haotong Yang (Peking University), Zilong Zheng (BIGAI), Xiyuan Wang (Peking University), Muhan Zhang (Peking University)
relevance_why: The paper proposes a method for improving long context understanding in large language models, which could be beneficial for tasks involving audio-language modeling and possibly enhancing the understanding of long audio inputs.
background: Improving the ability of large language models to comprehend lengthy contexts, allowing better responses to queries that span extensive information.
contribution: This paper introduces Long Input Fine-Tuning (LIFT) to solve long-context understanding challenges in large language models, achieving improved performance on various long-context tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing long-context models often struggle with computational limits and context window size, reducing their effectiveness in handling extensive inputs.
technical_comparison.novelty: The LIFT method fine-tunes model parameters using long inputs without systematically increasing their context windows or relying on extensive retraining.

key_innovation: LIFT dynamically adapts the model's parameters to incorporate long input information, allowing models to retain knowledge beyond their context windows.
real_world_impact: Such improvements can enhance performance in applications requiring detailed information retrieval from long texts, contributing to smarter AI in content generation and summarization tasks.
limitations: The paper notes that while LIFT improves long-context performance, it can diminish in-context learning abilities.

new_terms.Long Input Fine-Tuning (LIFT): **Long Input Fine-Tuning (LIFT)** is a framework for improving the long-context comprehension of large language models by adapting model parameters based on lengthy input data.
